data.title: What a disappointment
data.text: The service was perfect.  Too bad the food they served was so awful.  The gyoza tasted as if it came from Trader Joe's, the chicken skewers were tasteless, the Japanese pancakes was an abomination.  The portions were small except for the pancake but we could not eat it. Dinner for two was $75 and we left hungry and very disappointed

data.title: Reliable standout
data.text: Ms. Geek and I have been several times for dinner and lunch. The Okonomiyaki is better than any I've had in Japantown in SF -- it's worth the wait. The wine list is particularly adventurous for a Napa restaurant -- not afraid of the rest of the world. I'm not a big Sake drinker but the selection looks good.

data.title: We were happy
data.text: I'm surprised by the mixed reviews. We have only been here once & did not have the yakitori, opting for appetizers, salad & noodles. We got the Potato & Smoked Trout Croquettes, which were delicious. So was another appetizer that had corn & other goodies in a creamy sauce, scooped up with homemade potato chips (sorry, don't remember the name). I also don't remember the name of our salad, but it too was great. The only thing we found disappointing, was the blandness of the ramen noodle dish. Last was the green tea ice cream with sesame honeycomb candy & miso caramel sauce. Wow, that was uniquely delicious. We left full & all of this came out to ~$45 total. We didn't have any drinks, but the price still would have been reasonable if we had. I guess the mixed reviews comes down to your culinary experience, what you order & when you go, as the place was not too loud when we were there.

data.title: Delicious Lunch
data.text: I am always happy to see Napa branching out from chi-chi wine country fair or mexican, so this is a welcome addition.  I found lunch delightful.  The corn fritters are gluttony incarnate.  Their Donburi was lovely, although a bit too much rice.  The Katsu was crisp and fresh.  I had a strange cocktail, that I am still not sure if I enjoyed.  The ambiance is worth a visit all by itself, with oddly curved walls and lots of wood.  They have an ice cream room - so even though I don't usually go for sundaes, we did the build you own for dessert.  I hear dinner is spectacular.

data.title: At Least an "A" for Effort
data.text:
I don't get it.  Once again, I let nostalgia derail my expectations.  Hokkaido is the origin of robatayaki style awesomeness and I was hoping to get just a sliver of that experience:  Intimate (if somewhat smoky) setting, reasonably affordable, chicken-parts-on-a-stick goodness, washed down with mugs of cold beer.

This experience was:  hip, dark & weirdly spot lit, LOUD, too expensive for the style of food, with the grill shunned off into a corner, and service was herky-jerky. (Also my mother would slap me if she found out that I paid $15 for okonomiyaki - cuz that, like yakisoba, is one of those foods you make at home when you are scraping the bottom of the pantry/fridge - or it's a cheap (good) street snack- but not $15, yo!)   We had no reservations, but were promptly seated at the bar when we went around 5.  It got very busy and very loud no time at all.

We ordered the corn fritters, maitake mushrooms, bonjiri (chicken butt!) and ramen.  The "appetizers" came out first, but spaced 20 minutes between each dish.  Fritters were good. The grilled maitake was just crispy mushroom on sticks- no seasoning, no oil, nothing. Bonjiri was really good, but so small - baby chicken butts.  

And the ramen ...totally bougie, "haole" style.  It came out at least 20 mins after the last appetizer was taken away.  Dark, molasses dark broth, which was actually pretty tasty.  But they went and put fresh sliced cabbage and sesame seeds in it (Like dumping odd katsu-bento garnish items into the bowl. That's weird!) The green onion was chunky sliced, so it wouldn't come up with the noodles as you ate it. People hopping on this ramen trend don't understand, it's not just a bowl of brown broth, with noodles and random stuff thrown in there.  (Dude, that's Top Ramen, not "ramen-ramen"). It was good for a bowl of noodles, just wasn't ramen. 

We waited an oddly long amount of time before we finally flagged the bartender for the check.

The soft-serve at the window was FANTASTIC!  Miso caramel with whiskey butterscotch sauce was the best dessert I've had in a long time.  I'll pop by the soft-serve window just for that, but I'll skip the main fare -  and hibachi that stuff on my own at home.

data.title: Awesome Lunch
data.text:
Went here for a work lunch and ordered a mix of stuff for lunch. All of it was excellent. Flavors were lovely, food was prepared to perfection (the chicken on the salad was divine!) and atmosphere is great. I have never seen so much wood in a restaurant. They event went as far as putting cloth/rug under the wood tables in the booth so you don't scratch your legs or clothing on rough wood.  Definitely would go back for lunch.  Price were pretty reasonable too.

I have heard, however that dinner is a different matter - smaller plates and higher prices. I can't speak to this but wanted to throw it in there so people reading this don't get a wrong impression and show up to a super expensive dinner.

data.title: Not sure what all the hype is about - food good, but really over priced
data.text: I was tempted to give this a 2 rating based on what I expected the quality to be. - but settled on average.  We've read about this restaurant in the newspaper and on line.  When in Napa a couple of weeks ago, we decided to give it a try.  Walking distance from our hotel, which is always a good thing.  Overall the food was OK and service was average - only a couple of complaints, but the bill was $94.50 for the two of us.  Beer and sake prices are on the high end.  For example, we had a 8 or 9 oz pour of Junmal - it was $19.00.  Could buy the whole bottle in the grocery store for about $22 - $29. We mostly ate meat on a stick, tried 5.  Prices ranged from $7-$8.50 for two sticks.  We normally pay between $3 and $4 for the same quality/quantity.  The chicken hearts were ill prepared, the hard part on the top was not trimmed off and that part was inedible.  Chef tried to tell us that was the way they were prepared in Japan. The real clincher though was the Albacore for $11.  4 pieces, sliced so thin they were somewhat transparent and each piece was about a 1 inch square.  On top of that they wanted to charge you about $5.00 for fresh grated wasabi.  So when in Napa, if I want Japanese, I would go back to Morimoto.  Meat on a stick - pick another food style,  Asian - there's a great little Thai place on the main drag, wish I could remember the name.  Mid-range dining at fine dining prices.

data.title: Hidden on Coombs Street
data.text:
Starting with an impressive wooden door and overscaled wooden ceiling, you
know that this is not your typical Japanese restaurant. Highlights include
a wait team that is superior, friendly but not intrusive.  We ordered five small
plates and each was perfectly spiced .  Do not skip the ice cream dessert,
the best frozen soft creme and I am an expert in ice cream.  Thye intend to
have a walk up window soon, so that you can order a walking dish for a
hot afternoon

data.title: Dissapointing
data.text:
Maybe it's us. The reviews have been quite good. The interior has been elegantly done. The servers were quite friendly. 

But the food was not good and it was served with no rhythm or reason. On the whole the broth starter was sort of weak and not too tasty. It's nice that they smoke their own fish to make it and the set up behind the grill is pretty. It would have been better if it was good. 

We focused on skewers. Not one was other than overlooked and most were not edible.  It's forgivable at the early opening stage but certainly not what you want the signature dishes to be. 

The bar is crazy loud. So much so that at our table as far away as possible from it we were yelling at each other. That beautiful wood paneling and ceiling really reverberates. 

We love the attempt to bring something new to our town and we hope it gets better.

data.title: We gave it another shot - too bad for us!
data.text:
Our last visit was within a month of their opening and the service was really lacking, the food was OK, and the fried rice was really good.  This time, the service was fine, but the food was just bleh.  Underseasoned, underpresented and underwhelming overall.  We walked out of there having spent $140 for two of us, and felt like we got worked over.
All the chicken yakitori were fine, quite a bit underseasoned, but it's just about 2 oz. of chicken on a stick on a plate, period.  We also had a tuna rice dish with veg & 'japanese mayonaisse' which was a bowl of mushyness, no texture, all soft, needed salt, sriracha, everything - that was as a replacement for the pork ramen which was just horrible - the noodles were starchy, nasty tasting things, the pork was half fat, and it was underseasoned as well!
At this point, after 2 tries, we're gonna call this one a dog and move on.  If you want creative asian-inspired cuisine, try Rae Set.

data.title: Underwhelming and overpriced
data.text:
Had dinner here tonight and after having this style of food in Japan and Australia was quite underwhelmed. 

Staff were friendly and service was good, not great just good. Fit out and ambience is very good. The disappointment was the food and the associated cost. We took the waitress's recommendations and ordered some sashimi which was great, beef short rib which was tender but lacking any real flavour without adding soy. Then onto the Squab @$30 which was a very small serving of one butterflied bird which  lacked any real flavour apart from the over seasoned skin. We also tried the corn (great) and chicken thigh yakitori which was coated in salt again. 

We finished with their signature soft serve ice cream which was delicious. However for the $130 bill for 2 with 3 Sprites and no alcoholic drinks I thought this was about $60 over priced.

data.title: Very unique menu offerings
data.text:
A group of friends met for happy hour and a small bite.  After reading through the menu, it was incredible the number of unusual items they had while also having the standard yakitori and rice dishes to share.  I didn't try it, but the homemade ice cream looks amazing.
The decor and remodeling was really pretty, however due to block walls and high ceiling, the noise level is pretty loud at peak times.

data.title: Wow!  A stunner!  Everything is amazing!
data.text: It is so rare to have a restaurant be amazing right from the beginning.  We have been here four times already, and it just opened.  We have tried the yakitori (skewers), rice bowls, noodle bowls, appetizers, and raw fish - everything was perfect.  Plus the wine list is great - I can even get an Austrian Gruner Veltliner - the beers are good, too.  We are so lucky to have this place in Napa!  The Japanese soft ice cream is delicious as are the cones they make in-house.

data.title: Ichiban-the Best!
data.text: In Japanese, “ichiban”means “number one” or “the best”.  I’ve followed the star evolution of chef Curtis DiFede from Oliveto to Oenotri and now to his newest innovation, the Japanese inspired Miminashi.  Here he incorporates traditional Japanese elements with a vibrant flair for authenticity with a fresh twist. Unless you can read Japanese, you need to know the address of this Izakaya inspired pub as the name is scrolled in small Japanese characters only with the number 821 below (as in 821 Coombs Street, Napa, California). The beautifully handmade carved doors are a nod to Mt. Fuji while the modern, hip, yet casual décor includes booths and tables to accommodate various numbers of diners. The staff was welcoming and sat our group of four immediately. Warm clothes to wash our hands were delivered on handsome wood pads, a much-appreciated surprise after a day of Napa Valley festivities. When we asked, we were brought water, both sparkling and still. The sommelier has an excellent knowledge of sakes, wines, and beers and was happy to recommend a beverage that would compliment our food. The menu changes according to what’s fresh on the farm and fisheries. On our evening we shared many dishes including the beef tataki sashimi, stone tree farm beets, Matthiasson farm peaches, and house-made gyoza from the sashimi, vegetable, and noodle column.  The beets and peaches were colorful standouts. Under Yakitori, we were adventuresome and ordered Tan-Moto, beef tongue, Moo-shoniku (chicken thigh) Shishito peppers, and the fabulous Maitake mushrooms, which have an interesting back-story. We also shared main course of Yellowfin tuna.  Without exception, everything was truly delicious with unique and individualized tastes. All plates are portioned for sharing with chopsticks (you can ask for silverware), and it’s a fun way to experience these very different flavors of Japan.  We finished our meal with their coconut soft cream in a waffle bowl.  The dessert specials for the night included a peach crumble and a mango freeze, both sounded delicious, but we settled on the signature ice cream. Guests can sit at the bar or at the counter to watch the cooks work over the wood fire. Walkser on the street can watch through the window as the person makes the soft cream. Be aware that the noise level is high in Miminashi and reservations are “a must”. (The place was packed at 5:30pm.) Arigato, Curtis, for designing a novel eatery that is original and inventive. Looking forward to the next meal to see what’s new on the menu.

data.title: Headache inducing noise level
data.text:
The waitress couldn't hear us, we couldn't hear each other and between 7 and 8pm there were more decibels than the Indianapolis 500. Not a pleasant dining situation. 
The food was good...we had the Shrimp fried rice, potato croquettes, grilled corn and mushrooms.
I was surprised there were only 2 noodle dishes, both ramen, one with chicken and  one with pork. Almost no vegetarian options.

data.title: Fantastic flavors and textures
data.text: Other than sushi and teriyaki, I had never eaten at a Japanese cuisine restaurant, so wasn't sure what to expect. Wow, what a culinary delight! We were blown away by one great dish after another (3 of us, so sampled many dishes). Very intelligent and high quality wine list. I'm not a salad person, and I fell in love with their gem salad with a couple of veggies and a miso vinagerette (sounds plain, but remember, I'm not a salad guy and I'd go back just for this). 17 or 18 yakitori (meat on a skewer) are offered, these are luscious and safe if you're not sure about Japanese food. Waiters and staff are very patient and knowledgable, answer questions about the menu without making you feel like the only dummy in the room. Then, the soft serve ice cream in a waffle bowl at the end will get you to eat beyond your capacity. I absolutely CAN'T WAIT to go back and eat my way through the menu. If you're in a hurry, their bar seats 15-20 people and was busy all night. Clearly a hit with locals. If you're a foodie, check this place out asap

data.title: They don't quite have it down yet.
data.text:
We had a rez, but chose to sit at the bar, which was a mistake, it turns out.  The bartender either couldn't hear us, or had a bad memory because he asked twice what our order was, brought the yakitori potatoes instead of the croquettes (which he recommended) and forgot the meatballs, but they were on the check anyway.

OK, the food took a long time to come out, but it was really tasty.  The kitchen sent out a little tablespoon of dashi with a piece of daikon in it as an amuse bouche, but it was nasty, room-temperature watery broth.  The gyoza was delicious, the chicken hearts were great, the meatballs maybe would have been good, but they never showed up.  The fried rice with oysters and shrimp was fabulous.

It's a beautiful room, and they're serving great food, they just need to get their service together, and hire consciously - service was bad, food was great = "average" experience.
